Playtime to 100%: About 1 hour
Keywords: visual novel, shoujo-ai, free

This is a short, kinetic novel (no choices) about a girl named Toma who has an affinity for graveyards. In one of her usual haunts she encounters another girl who tells her the titular sad story of the young Emmeline Burns. It's a tragic and emotional tale, but don't worry, it's not all doom and gloom.

While the story is fairly straightforward, it's well written and engaging, and the characters are fleshed out well in the short playtime. The pastel-toned art work is gorgeous, the music is nice and atmospheric, and the whole game has a gothic tone to it that somehow blends perfectly with the sugary visuals. The only downside is some dodgy sound effects that only pop up briefly.

And the best part - it's free! So there's really no reason not to give it a shot.

reviewText:
Why is this so short? I mean stretching it any further would probably ruin the story but all the same I did not want this to end.

Created by the same team behind Asphyxia, this short story is far lighter than the previous title and yet still just as powerful from an emotional perspective, maybe even more so. It keeps the same style, even including an extra scene that references the characters from Asphyxia, but utilises a smaller cast and location to tell a tightly-woven story that works beautifully. The first character we meet is Toma, a young girl who enjoys going around graveyards and learning about the stories of those buried there (something that I relate too, quite a bit). She meets an old-fashioned girl named Emily who tells her the story of Emmeline Burns, how she had a romantic relationship with her best friend Cornelia and how a problem with her father‚Äôs business led to her untimely death. I found myself drawn to these characters instantly, and actually felt more invested than I was in Asphyxia. Maybe it‚Äôs because it‚Äôs got a lighter tone (which is weird considering I‚Äôm naturally drawn to darker stories as a rule) or maybe I‚Äôm just a sucker for Yuri romances (which I am) but either way it shows the talent of the creator in their ability to construct a story. After all this is a charming tale with a tragic touch, as well as taking a surprising look at the theme of identity that I wasn‚Äôt initially expecting. It‚Äôs simple yet effective, enough to give The Sad Story of Emmeline Burns a permanent place in my heart.

I do not have enough recommendations to give, check this out to experience beautiful art, lovely music and an utterly emotional tale that will tug at your heartstrings incessantly. And if you enjoyed Asphyxia then you'll enjoy seeing more of that teams' amazing talent on display.

And all of this for free. Ebi-Hime, why do you spoil me so?

reviewText:
I don't know how to feel about this visual novel (and visual novel it is- no gameplay, no choices to be had, etc).

On the one hand, it's free. The visuals and soundtrack are pleasant, much better than I was expecting. The writing was above average as well, which was another welcome surprise. And it's about women who love women, which I am always eager to see.

It's very short. I completed it entirely in less than an hour.

On the other hand. The story was... rather poorly done, imo. The framing with Toma wasn't necessary at all to tell the story of Emmeline, which itself was... trite?  Emmeline and Cornelia just seemed like typical yuri stereotypes rather than their own characters-- which is really weird considering they're the ones you see for most of the game. I wasn't moved by their tragedy whatsoever. It was oddly paced and made for poor connection with the characters.

On a nit-pickier note, I felt like they were perhaps a bit too verbose for 14 year olds. I get that it's the 1800's, but something about the way Emmeline and Cornelia spoke really didn't fit with the fact they were 14. For some reason I just don't feel like 14 year olds, even in the 1800's, spoke quite so poetically.

The sound effects are truly abysmal and ear-piercing. They completely ruin the soundtrack when they play.

This all being said, I realize this was made for a game jam, and perhaps the story would have been improved had there been more time sown into it. (Or even just certain aspects- less time on the buildup with Toma and more time on Emmeline's story.)

But... based on the great reviews, I was expecting something pretty noteworthy, something that would tug at my gay little heartstrings. What I got was just a mediocre and predictable story that I didn't feel focused as much on lesbian love as it advertises.

If you're looking for something great that is saturated with LGBT goodness (like I was), I would say you might want to look elsewhere. If you're looking for a quick (and quickly done) yuri story, well... here it is. It's alright for a free one-shot, but frankly I was so disappointed with the story that I don't think I could recommend it.

reviewText:
TL;DR: Short kinetic (visual) novel about identity and romance between girls.

The Sad Story of Emmeline Burns is a kinetic novel, meaning it is totally linear and has no choices. It begins with a girl named Toma, whose story is also a bit sad, as she's a girl struggling with her teens identity. She takes the role of both narrator and protagonist.

She meets a coeval girl, Emily, who recites her story to her. While Emily is not exactly the protagonist, she's still given a major role in the novel, hardly surprising given the title of the novel. The plot involves romance (in that poetic sense) between girls.

I found the story not exactly tear-inducingly sad but rather melancholic or depressing instead. That said, it isn't a bad story and it ends with a happy or at least hopeful tone. Perspective alternates between Toma and Emily.

The visuals are gorgeous (I liked the detailed artstyle) and characters have many facial and bodily expressions, even if not everything described is shown visually. There is no voice acting. The background music consists of beautiful, yet melancholic piano tunes.

I read it in about 75 minutes. The overall quality is good, and I detected only a couple of typos. It's also free and has a bunch of achievements, got for reading the thing through. If you're not bothered by a romance between girls and you like reading, check this one out on a rainy day.

reviewText:
The Sad Story of Emmeline Burns is a KINETIC NOVEL. Not to be confused with a visual novel, in which you make choices to decide where the story will go. It's a KINETIC NOVEL, essentially a story book in the form of a game which you can't make choices or choose your own adventure.

This is my first true KINETIC novel. And it was a free kinetic novel on Steam and the art was gorgeous, so i decided to give it a read. I didnt' learn it was a kinetic novel until after i started playing. Even going through the options menu there's a 'skip after choice' option, but there are no choices in this game to make to redirect the story.

For a kinetic novel, the story should be paramount. So let's get onto the bulk of the review:

There are sort of 2 stories in 1, but as the title suggests, what's mostly focused on is the Sad Story of Emmeline Burns. Her story is set in Victorian England with her best friend as they discover they have lesbian feelings toward one another and we see them have somewhat of a secret love affair over their shared summer.  There are a few mentions of each girl's family: Emmeline's father always having to prove himself to everyone in the world, Cornelia's strict mother who is very well meaning. We don't see them, but they are mentioned. This story is told to us by Emmeline herself to Toma, who is supposed to be the actual protagonist. How Toma met Emmeline is that she wandered to a graveyard in order to get away from the world and sulk a bit and Toma herself has a friend named Hattie, who is one of her only friends who she's growing lesbian feelings for as well...

That's the non-spoiler version... But you can probably guess what happens...

Honestly i thought this game was going to be a lot different than the title suggested. The title suggested this was going to be somewhat of a murder mystery revolved around a dead girl namely Emmeline Burns. Instead you got a story within a story and apperently Toma was supposed to be the protagonist... There's no mystery. There's no suspence. You can pretty much figure out what's going to happen ahead of time...

So needless to say, story wise, I am dissapointed and left wanting more. There's a lot of lost potential here:
- Toma is set up as a really interesting protagonist. She doesn't like her name, she was raised by a single mom who has this ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•y sounding sister who stole the name she was originally going to give to Toma while she was pregnant, Toma's mother loves going to grave yards and she's OBSESSED with history and ancestry! There's this whole family drama that could be focused on, but it's surprisingly absent! It's all talked about in the intro, but we're not shown anything else related to this drama!

- Toma is an interesting character, but you honestly could've scrapped her from the game entirely! Her subplot is so minescule that it probably would've worked better as it's own game than lumped into this game that wants to focus on these 2 lesbian girls in the Victorian era! This applies to Hattie as well. She's supposed to be Toma's only friend, but she just appears toward the end after the story within the story is told... Like Toma, she could've been scrapped out of the game entirely. If you really want to use these characters, the game should've been a murder mystery with Hattie and Toma having the detective's perspective OR they should just have their own game...

-Emmeline and Cornelia could've been delved into more as characters. Why not show us their families? How they live in Victorian society! Emmeline brings up at one point that there was a boy who tried to hit on her but she denied him! That could've been interesting to see for ourselves! How could Emmeline and Cornelia handle being lesbians in such a conservative period? I would've loved to see that! The romance between them is sweet, but if you wanna go full drama, why not show us what they're like when their apart? Show us their lives apart from eachother, show us what has driven them to love eachother, show us more of their families who are important to them  and to some of the 'plot'.

- The overall 'plot' is just sort of 'meh'... Toma is supposed to be our heroine, but the game so desperately wants to focus on Emmeline that i forget whether or not there is an actual plot...

As you can probably tell, i have a lot more complaints about the story than i do good points... But even though i do have these gripes at all this missing potential, there are some minor good things about the game:

1. THE ART IS GORGEOUS. It really sets the mood and it's like looking at a painting in a museum. 4. IT'S FREE!

I expected this game to be much shorter, being a free game and all I suppose...

I need to first off say that this isn't really a game at all.  There are no choices to make at all, no puzzles to solve, nothing to do but read and click your mouse to move to the next part of the dialogue or story.

It is a beautiful story that is both uplifting and very sad, but mostly inspirational and this virtual novel has some nice art work as well.

It's a good enough story that I feel guilty for not paying some kind of price to have experienced it.  It's a well crafted story that attempts to show us the beauty of love, loving yourself regardless of who you are, and how important it is to never take a single day for granted.

I enjoyed it very much, even if it did feel like it tried to push 'female on female' sexuality on the reader a little too heavy for my tastes and comfort level.  Regardless, it gets it's points across in shining fashion and I will not knock it for the path it used to get there.

I didn't realize this was a yuri until it happened.

The Sad Story of Emmeline Burns is a visual novel, though you are simply just reading through the story. You aren't able to make any decisions throughout the story.

You are introduced as Toma Andrews, a girl who has felt everything that has happened to her and why she feels she is this way is because of her name.
